questions.text: During ward rounds, you encounter a patient who has been admitted with esophageal carcinoma. What is the most likely presentation for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids

options.label: B
options.text: Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

questions.correct_answer: B. Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids
questions.explanation:
Carcinoma Esophagus

Types
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • Adenocarcinoma

Risk Factors
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Smoking, Alcohol, Hot beverages, N-nitroso foods,
  • Adenocarcinoma: Obesity, Gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett's esophagus

Clinical Features
  • Progressive dysphagia (initially for solids followed by liquids), Anorexia, Weight loss, Odynophagia, and Regurgitation.
  • Advanced symptoms: Hoarseness, Aspiration, Choking, etc.

Investigation
  • Endoscopy: Tumor visualisation, Biopsies, Chromoendoscopy, NBI
  • Barium contrast study: Tumor as ulcerated/stenotic lesion
  • Bronchoscopy: Check airway spread
  • Endoscopic & Percutaneous Ultrasonography:
    • EUS for staging tumour (T stage) and para esophageal nodes Percutaneous ultrasound of cervical nodes with FNA
  • CT scan: Distant node assessment
  • FDG-PET scan: Detects nodes/metastases, not for tumour staging

questions.text: An intern assists in laparoscopic surgery, and the resident explains the instruments and operating ports. The surgeon then asks, "What is the angle between the camera port and the working port called?"
questions.explanation:
Angles of laparoscopy

Azimuth angle

It is the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery; the ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° to avoid clashing of the instruments.

Manipulation angle

It is the angle between two working ports, and the ideal angle for this is 60°.

Elevation angle

This term is more related to the vertical positioning of instruments or the camera in relation to the surgical field, not the angle between ports; the ideal angle for this is also 60°.

questions.text: What is the Truelove and Witts classification used for?
questions.explanation:
Truelove and Witts classification for Ulcerative Colitis

Severity

Stool Frequency

Systemic Symptoms and signs

Mild

<4 stools/day

No systemic signs of toxicity

Moderate

>4 stools/day

Fever, abdominal pain, Elevated ESR, CRP

Severe

>6 stools/day

Fever, tachycardia, anaemia, systemic illness, hypoalbuminemia, Elevated ESR, CRP

Fulminant

>10 stools/day

Continuous bleeding, fever, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness & distension, “Toxic megacolon” (progressive colonic dilation, an indication for emergency surgery) in severe cases

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective gene mutation: A. Familial adenomatous polyposis i. SMAD4 B. Juvenile polyposis ii. STK11 C. Tuberous sclerosis iii. APC gene D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome iv. TSC1
questions.explanation:
A. Familial adenomatous polyposis

iii. APC gene

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by APC gene mutations on chromosome 5.
  • It is characterised by numerous intestinal polyps, which, if left untreated, have a high risk of developing colorectal cancer

B. Juvenile polyposis

i. SMAD4

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder that commonly affects children under 5 years of age,
  • It is characterised by pedunculated polyps, usually less than 3 cm in diameter.
  • It is linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF-β signalling pathway.

C. Tuberous sclerosis

iv. TSC1

  • It is a neurocutaneous disorder resulting from mutations in the TSC1 (hamartin) or TSC2 (tuberin) genes.
  • Patients exhibit neurological symptoms like seizures, along with skin abnormalities.
  • The syndrome also includes hamartomatous polyps in the intestine.

D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

ii. STK11

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the STK11 gene.
  • It presents around 11 years of age and is characterised by
    • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of melena that contains gastric mucosa and acute intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following structure was found, what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Definition

Congenital true diverticulum of the small intestine, resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.

Rule of 2’s

2% population, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2 inches in length, 2 types of ectopic tissue (gastric, pancreatic), 2 years most common presentation, 2:1 male predominance.

Clinical Features

Painless bleeding (melena), intestinal obstruction, diverticulitis, volvulus, intussusception.

Diagnosis

Meckel’s scan (Tc-99m pertechnetate scan for ectopic gastric mucosa).

Treatment

Surgical resection (diverticulectomy or segmental resection) if symptomatic.

questions.text: A patient with grade 4 hemorrhoids underwent surgery, identify the instrument.
questions.explanation:
Grade of Hemorrhoids

Treatment Options

Grade 1 (No prolapse)

Lifestyle modification, fiber, sitz bath, topical agents

Grade 2 (Prolapse, spontaneous reduction)

Rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared coagulation

Grade 3 (Prolapse, manual reduction needed)

Rubber band ligation, surgical excision if persistent symptoms

Grade 4 (Irreducible prolapse)

Surgical options: Hemorrhoidectomy (excision or stapler), laser hemorrhoidoplasty

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents with sudden onset acute abdominal pain , constipation for 1 day , persistent hiccups , and occasional vomiting . An abdominal X-ray was performed. Identify the pathology.

Caecal Volvulus

Cause

Twisting of caecum & ascending colon

X-ray Sign

"Coffee bean" or "Omega loop" sign

"Comma" or "Kidney bean" sign

Bowel Dilatation

Sigmoid colon massively distended

Dilated caecum, displaced medially

Management

Endoscopic detorsion or surgery

Surgery (right hemicolectomy if gangrenous)

questions.text: A 34-year-old male undergoes an open appendectomy for acute appendicitis. The choice of incision was McBurney's incision. Postoperatively, after a few days, he presents with pain and bulging in the right lower quadrant, which is diagnosed as an indirect inguinal hernia. Which nerve injury during the appendectomy is most likely responsible for this complication?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

1. Wound infection

The MC postoperative complication involves infection at the surgical site.

2. Intraabdominal abscess

Collection of pus within the abdominal cavity, typically due to infection.

3. Ileus

Temporary cessation of bowel function, leading to abdominal distension and discomfort.

4. Venous thrombosis leading to embolism

Formation of blood clots in the veins, which can travel to the lungs or other parts of the body.

5. Portal pyaemia (Pylephlebitis)

Infection and thrombosis of the portal vein, a rare but serious complication.

6. Adhesive intestinal obstruction

Formation of scar tissue causing bowel obstruction; MC late complication

7. Fecal fistula

Leakage from the appendiceal stump.

8. Nerve injury

Injury to the Ilioinguinal nerve and iliohypogastric nerve

questions.text: A child with recurrent vomiting undergoes an x-ray, as shown below. What is the most likely electrolyte imbalance in this patient?
Which nerve is most commonly injured during indirect inguinal hernia surgery?
A patient underwent surgery for pilonidal sinus, which type of flap is used in this surgery?
questions.explanation:
Treatment Type

Description

Conservative Treatment
  • For mild cases: cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
  • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser in less complex cases.

Acute Abscess Treatment
  • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess.
  • Thorough cleaning of the abscess cavity to remove granulation tissue and hair.

Surgical Treatment

Procedures include:

  • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
  • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
  • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
  • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
  • Flap Procedures: Used if initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs.

questions.text: Which incision is most commonly used for an appendectomy?
questions.explanation:
Incision Type

Description

Common Uses

Abdominal Incisions

Midline

Longitudinal cut through the linea alba, bloodless access

Exploratory laparotomy, trauma surgery, emergency surgeries

Periumbilical

Incisions around the umbilicus, avoiding the umbilical stalk

Laparoscopy, umbilical hernia repairs, postpartum tubal ligation

Pararectus

Along the semilunar line, lateral to the rectus abdominis

Abdominal wall hernia repairs, stoma creation, pelvic surgeries

Paramedian

Lateral to the linea alba, access to lateral viscera

Lateral abdominal structures,

Reduced hernia risk

Kocher/Subcostal

Inferior and parallel to the costal margin, access to upper abdomen structures

Gallbladder, biliary tree, pancreas, liver transplants, epigastric surgeries

Grindiron/

McBurney/

Lanz

Lower abdomen incisions, typically for appendectomy

Appendectomy (right side), sigmoid diverticulitis (left side), cosmetic appendectomy

Thoracoabdominal

From 7th intercostal space to the umbilicus, exposes thoracic and abdominal organs

Retroperitoneal masses, pleural space, distal esophagus, abdominal organs

Thoracic Incisions

Thoracotomy

Access to thoracic structures, various approaches

Lung transplants, cardiac surgeries, trauma

Median Sternotomy

Vertical incision dividing the sternum, wide access to the mediastinum

Open-heart surgery, anterior mediastinal tumor resection

Trapdoor

Complex incision, supraclavicular, sternal, and thoracotomy components

Penetrating trauma, aortic arch aneurysms, complex cardiovascular access

Infraclavicular

A transverse incision just below the clavicle for subclavian vessel access

Thoracic outlet syndrome, subclavian vessel surgeries

Supraclavicular

Superior to the clavicle, providing access to the subclavian vessels

Trauma, thoracic outlet syndrome

Neck Incisions

Collar

Incision above the sternal notch for thyroid surgeries

Thyroid surgery, mid-neck structures

Traumatic Neck

Along the sternocleidomastoid muscle for trauma

Vascular or traumatic neck injuries

Tracheostomy

Vertical/horizontal incision superior to the thyroid for tracheostomy

Airway management in patients needing long-term ventilation

Pelvic Incisions

Pfannenstiel

Transverse incision above the pubic symphysis

Cesarean section, pelvic, urologic, and orthopaedic surgeries

Maylard/Cherney

Above pubic tubercle, provides access to pelvic structures

Hysterectomy, pelvic lymph node dissection, lower pelvis surgeries

Inguinal

Above and parallel to the inguinal ligament

Inguinal hernia repair, urologic surgeries (cryptorchidism, varicocele)

McEvedy

Vertical incision for femoral hernia repair

Femoral hernia repair (obsolete now due to high hernia recurrence rate)

Gibson

Above inguinal ligament, arc to the lateral rectus sheath

Kidney transplantation, retroperitoneal access (iliac vessels, ureter)

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting, binge drinking, and heavy meals presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Pneumoperitoneum is noted on X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Esophageal perforation

Definition

A breach in the esophageal wall leads to leakage and increased morbidity and mortality

Causes

Iatrogenic injury, spontaneous (Boerhaave's syndrome), foreign bodies, corrosive substances, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal cancer

Symptoms
  • Varies by cause and location:
  • Iatrogenic (recent instrumentation)
  • Boerhaave's (vomiting, chest pain, emphysema)
  • Cervical (neck pain, etc.)

Diagnosis

Imaging: Chest X-ray, contrast swallow studies, CT scan

Management
  • Seal perforation, ensure drainage, supportive measures (nutrition, cardiorespiratory support, sepsis control)
  • Conservative Management: Suitable for stable patients: antibiotics, nil by mouth, observation
  • Endoscopic Interventions: Visualization, retrieval, sealing with clips/stents, nasogastric tube placement
  • Surgical Intervention: Required for significant sepsis, large perforations, pleural involvement, delayed presentation
  • Surgical Options: Primary repair, controlled fistula creation, esophageal diversion, esophagectomy (rare)

A 60-year-old male patient presents with a left groin swelling for a few years, which increases in size on standing and decreases when lying down. On examination, the swelling shows a positive cough impulse. What is the appropriate management?

options.label: D
options.text: Reduction of contents, repair defects and reinforcement with mesh

questions.correct_answer: D. Reduction of contents, repair defects and reinforcement with mesh
questions.explanation:
Bassini's Repair:

  • Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair.
  • Higher recurrence rates.

 

Shouldice Repair involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's.

 

Modified Shouldice: A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement.

 

 

TEP

TAPP

Procedure

Surgery done above the peritoneum

Surgery done beneath the peritoneum

Advantages
  • Lower risk of bowel injury and peritoneal complications.
  • Reduced risk of adhesions.
  • Larger working space
  • Better visualisation

Disadvantages

Smaller working spaces can make the procedure more technically challenging.
  • A higher risk of bowel injury and adhesion formation due to entry into the peritoneal cavity.
  • Potential for increased postoperative pain compared to TEP.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals rigidity and guarding. Abdominal X-ray shows air under the diaphragm. The patient is taken up for surgery, and an ileal perforation is noted intraoperatively with gross contamination of the abdomen with enteric and purulent content. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Common Uses

Reversibility

End Colostomy

Single opening from the proximal bowel. Often permanent.

Used when the distal bowel is removed or left in place, e.g., Hartmann's procedure

Often permanent

Loop Ileostomy

Loop of the bowel is brought to the surface, and an incision is made

Temporary diversion, especially in emergencies, and easily reversible

Usually temporary

Double-barrel Colostomy

Two stomas are created: one for faecal output and one for mucus discharge

Rarely used; can be for cases requiring both resection and exteriorization, offering mucous fistula

Can be temporary

Permanent Ileostomy

Terminal ileum is brought to the surface after a colectomy

Used when reconnection is not planned, often after total proctocolectomy for conditions like FAP

Permanent

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the abdomen for 1.5 years. She has a history of midline surgery. On examination, the swelling is 4 cm and is reducible with a palpable cough impulse. She is planning to undergo fascial closure with mesh repair. What is the most likely location of the mesh shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

 

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

 

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from the posterior rectus sheath; mesh is placed in this space, and the peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamocolumnar junction located more proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding?

Types

Description

Type I/Sliding Hiatus Hernia

The most common type.

The gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach slide up through the diaphragm.

Type II/Paraesophageal Hiatus Hernia

Part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm next to the oesophagus. The gastroesophageal junction remains in place.

Type III/Mixed Hiatus Hernia

Combines features of both sliding and paraesophageal hernias.

Type IV

Involves viscera other than the stomach in the hernial sac, like the colon.

Technique

Procedure

Advantages

Inlay

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Omphalocele

Gastroschisis

Definition

Congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents protrude through the base of the umbilicus.

Congenital abdominal wall defect is when abdominal contents protrude through a defect typically located to the right of the umbilicus.

Covering

The herniated organs are covered by two layers: Amnion (outer) and peritoneum (inner).

No membrane covers the exposed organs.

Associated conditions
  • Chromosomal abnormalities: Associated with Trisomy 13, 18, and 21.
  • Other congenital malformations affect multiple systems in the following order: cardiovascular> Muscular> gastrointestinal> genitourinary. (Mnemonic: "CM GIGU")
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: Can include hemihypertrophy, macroglossia, visceromegaly, omphalocele, and increased risk of hepatoblastoma.
  • Fewer chromosomal abnormalities compared to omphalocele.
  • Higher risk of intestinal atresia and dysfunction.

Prognosis

Generally poor due to associated congenital malformations, which are the most common cause of death.

Generally better than omphalocele due to fewer associated congenital anomalies.

Management
  • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects.
  • Larger defects may require:
  • Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex),
  • Porcine small intestinal submucosa-derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis),
  • Skin flap closure, or
  • Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure.
  • For giant omphaloceles, topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac.
  • Primary closure is typically done under general anesthesia and often requires admission to the NICU for postoperative ventilation.
  • Alternatively, a preformed silo can be placed at the bedside for gradual reduction, sometimes avoiding the need for general anesthesia altogether.

questions.text: Identify the image:
In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected?
A young patient in the first decade of life presents with grade II splenic injury with no active bleeding. What is the management?
questions.explanation:
American Association for the Surgery of Trauma - AAST Spleen Injury scale

Grade I (Minor Injury):
  • Subcapsular hematoma affects less than 10% of the splenic surface area.
  • Capsular tear that is less than 1 cm in depth without active bleeding.

Grade II:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma involving 10-50% of the splenic surface area.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma less than 5 cm in diameter.
  • Laceration between 1 and 3 cm in depth that doesn't involve trabecular vessels.

Grade III:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the splenic surface area or expanding hematoma.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma greater than 5 cm or expanding.
  • Laceration is more than 3 cm in depth or involves trabecular vessels.

Grade IV:

 
  • Laceration affects segmental or hilar vessels, with evidence of devascularisation involving more than 25% of the spleen.
  • Injury to the splenic parenchyma that results in major blood loss.
  • Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury or active bleeding within the splenic capsule

Grade V (Severe Injury):
  • Completely shattered spleen.
  • Vascular injury involving the splenic hilum that results in complete devascularization of the spleen.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an adult male patient with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region?
questions.explanation:
Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.

  • Associated Conditions:

    • Crohn’s disease

    • Tuberculosis

    • Lymphogranuloma venereum

    • Actinomycosis

    • Rectal duplication

    • Foreign bodies

    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

 

Clinical features

  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.

  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess

  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

questions.text: A barium swallow radiographic image of a woman with dysphagia is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. (Option A)

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumors.

T : Primary tumour

Tx : Tumour cannot be assessed

Aspect

Abdominal Rectopexy

Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's) (Option D)

  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time

Disadvantages

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the groin region, diagnosed as a direct inguinal hernia . Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition?

A 4-year-old child presents with a rectal polyp and painless rectal bleeding. Histopathological examination reveals enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. The child is diagnosed with a juvenile rectal polyp. Which of the following best describes the polyp in this case?
A 20-year-old female patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide. She is having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Alkali causes liquefaction, saponification, and thrombosis of vessels, leading to fibrosis and stricture.
  • Acid causes intense pylorospasm, antral pooling, coagulation necrosis, and eschar formation.

Acute Phase Management
  • Neutralization: vinegar/citrus for alkali; antacids/milk/egg whites for acid
  • Early endoscopy to assess severity and extent
  • Avoid emetics and sodium bicarbonate to prevent perforation

Management by Burn Degree

1st Degree Burns:

  • 48 hours observation; oral feeds resumed once saliva is swallowed painlessly
  • Regular follow-up endoscopy at 1st, 2nd, and 8th months to identify stricture

2nd & 3rd Degree Burns:

  • Fluid therapy, antibiotics, nutrition, PPIs and aerosolised steroids and resuscitation
  • Fiberoptic-guided airway intubation/tracheostomy, if necessary.
  • Endoscopic esophageal stenting, jejunostomy for feeding.
  • Laparoscopy for evaluation; laparotomy in unstable patients
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness.
  • Consider re-exploration after 36-48 hours if necessary.
  • Regular endoscopic dilatation for stricture
  • Use of various dilators (e.g., balloon, Savary-Gilliard, Eder-Puestow) for esophageal dilatation.

Surgical Considerations
  • Esophageal resection is technically difficult; bypass may be preferred
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness
  • A colonic conduit may be used if the stomach is diseased
  • Multiple strictures may require esophageal resection and colonic transposition

options.text: Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles

questions.correct_answer: B. Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles
questions.explanation:
Clinical Presentation
  • Typical onset: 3 to 6 weeks of age
  • Symptoms:
    • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting (Option A ruled out)
    • Visible gastric peristalsis
    • Palpable "olive-like" mass in the abdomen (hypertrophied pylorus), best felt from the left side
      • Test feed: Gastric peristalsis is seen passing from left to right across the abdomen, and in a relaxed (feeding) baby, the pyloric ‘tumor’ is palpable as an ‘olive’ in the right upper quadrant.
    • Dyselectrolytemias-
      • Hypochloremia
      • Hypokalemia due to persistent vomiting
      • Metabolic alkalosis. (Option D ruled out)

Ultrasound (Gold Standard)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Characteristic "doughnut sign" indicating thickened pyloric muscle
  • Diagnostic criteria:
    • Pyloric muscle thickness ≥ 4 mm
    • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
    • "Cervix sign" on long-axis view
    • "Target sign" on short-axis view

Barium Meal (Less Common)

Can assist in diagnosis but is less accurate than ultrasound, it reveals:

  • "String sign": Thin streak of contrast through narrowed pylorus
  • "Railroad track sign": Two thin lines of contrast indicating mild narrowing
  • "Double track sign": Similar to railroad track sign, indicating thickened muscle

questions.text: During an endoscopy, when a constriction is detected at the esophageal junction approximately 25 cm from the incisor, what is the likely cause?

A homosexual man presents with painful defecation and a protruding mass from the anal canal. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What is the appropriate course of action for managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Anal Canal Carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection: Strongly linked to anal canal cancer, particularly high-risk subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33)
  • Anal Intraepithelial Neoplasia (AIN): A precancerous condition significantly increases the risk of progression to anal canal cancer, especially from AIN II or III.
  • Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV-positive, transplant recipients)
  • Sexual Practices: Anal intercourse increases HPV transmission risk.
  • History of Other Genital Neoplasia: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)
  • Extensive Anogenital Condylomata: The presence of extensive anal warts linked to HPV infection

Clinical features
  • Pain
  • Bleeding
  • Palpable Mass
  • Pruritus (Itching)
  • Discharge
  • Incontinence
  • Fistulation (anterior tumour extension in women can create a fistula between the anus and vagina).
  • Appearance:
    • Anal margin tumours: Often resemble malignant ulcers with raised, hardened edges.
    • Anal canal tumours: Typically palpable as irregular, hardened, and tender ulcerated areas.
  • Lymph Node Involvement: Enlarged lymph nodes in the perirectal or groin regions may indicate cancer spread.

Investigations

  • Biopsy from the Anal Region: The primary diagnostic test to confirm the presence of carcinoma.
  • FNAC of Inguinal Nod (assess metastasis).
  • USG Abdomen (check for any spread of the disease).
  • MRI of the Perineum (assess the extent of the tumour).
  • Proctosigmoidoscopy: Assess the upper extent of the tumour within the anal canal.

Management

  • Chemoradiation (Nigro regimen): The preferred treatment modality for carcinoma of the anal canal. (Option C)
    • Chemotherapy Drugs: Commonly used drugs include 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), bleomycin, vincristine, and adriamycin.
    • Radiotherapy: Often used alone in advanced cases where the tumour is not resectable.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Abdominoperineal Resection (APR) with Colostomy: For persistent or recurrent disease after combined modality therapy (CMT), or for cases where the tumor does not respond to chemoradiation. (Option B ruled out)
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: Involves using 5-FU, cisplatin, and mitomycin C before surgery to shrink the tumour.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is made. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Fistula-in-Ano

A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Investigation

  • MRI: Maps the fistula tunnel and provides detailed images of the sphincter muscle and pelvic floor structures. (Investigation of choice) (Option D)
  • Endoscopic Ultrasound: It uses high-frequency sound waves to identify the fistula, sphincter muscles, and surrounding tissues.
  • Fistulography: An X-ray procedure using injected contrast to visualize the anal fistula tunnel. (1st investigation) (Option A ruled out)
  • Examination Under Anesthesia: Allows for thorough evaluation of the fistula tunnel and identification of potential complications.
  • Fistula Probe: A specialized instrument is inserted through the fistula to identify the fistula tunnel.
  • Anoscopy: A small endoscope is used to visualize the anal canal for assessment of fistulas during anoscopy.

Management:

Fistulotomy

  • Opening the fistula tract to heal by secondary intention.
  • Used for intersphincteric and trans-sphincteric fistula involving <30% of external sphincter; not for anterior fistula in women.

Fistulectomy

  • Removal of the fistula using diathermy cautery for better visualization of anatomy.
  • Effective for understanding the fistula's anatomy and extensions.

Setons

  • Materials are inserted into the fistula tract for drainage or gradual cutting.
  • Loose setons promote drainage; tight/cutting setons cut through muscle over time.

Advancement Flaps

  • Closing the internal opening with a flap of anorectal mucosa is used when the sphincter complex is not extensively indurated.
  • Effective for certain fistula configurations.

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

Perforation

  • Perforated gastrointestinal cancer
  • Perforated gastrointestinal ulcer

American Association for the Surgery of Trauma - AAST Spleen Injury scale

Grade I (Minor Injury):
  • Subcapsular hematoma affects less than 10% of the splenic surface area.
  • Capsular tear that is less than 1 cm in depth without active bleeding.

Grade II:
  • Subcapsular hematoma involving 10-50% of the splenic surface area.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma less than 5 cm in diameter.
  • Laceration between 1 and 3 cm in depth that doesn't involve trabecular vessels.

Grade III:
  • Subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the splenic surface area or expanding hematoma.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma greater than 5 cm or expanding.
  • Laceration is more than 3 cm in depth or involves trabecular vessels.

Grade IV:
  • Laceration affects segmental or hilar vessels, with evidence of devascularisation involving more than 25% of the spleen.
  • Injury to the splenic parenchyma that results in major blood loss.
  • Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury or active bleeding within the splenic capsule

Grade V (Severe Injury):
  • Completely shattered spleen.
  • Vascular injury involving the splenic hilum that results in complete devascularisation of the spleen.

questions.text: Severe, intractable pain in advanced rectum cancers is due to:
questions.explanation:
Technique

Indications

Local Excision

Suitable for early-stage cancers (T1 and selected T2) with good prognostic factors; preserves rectum and anal sphincter, minimizing bowel function impact.

Anterior Resection

Preferred for most cancers in the middle and lower rectum; involves removing affected rectal parts and reconnecting the colon to the remaining rectum.

Abdominoperineal Excision (APR)

Reserved for low-lying, extensive tumours unsuitable for sphincter-saving; involves removing rectum, anus, and surrounding tissues, creating a permanent colostomy.

Hartmann's Procedure

Involves removing the rectum and creating a temporary colostomy, suitable for elderly or frail patients.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Achalasia Cardia

Definition

Progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the oesophagal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry (Option C ruled out)

  • Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the oesophagus.
  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram) (Option A ruled out)

  • Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy (Option B ruled out)

  • Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris; it is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

Management

Pharmacological Treatments

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (reduce LES pressure)
  • Nitrates (relax the LES)
  • 5'-Phosphodiesterase Inhibitors (increase cyclic GMP to lower LES pressure)
  • Botulinum Toxin (Botox) Injections (temporarily paralyse LES muscles).

Non-Surgical Interventions

  • Bougie/Balloon Dilatation (ruptures LES muscle fibres to reduce pressure).

Surgical Treatments

  • Laparoscopic Heller's Cardiomyotomy (Most common)
    • The incision in the LES muscle to reduce pressure.
    • It is often combined with a fundoplication.
  • Partial Fundoplication
    • Prevents reflux; options include Dor or Toupet fundoplication.
  • Esophagectomy
    • Surgical removal of the esophagus (severe cases).

Endoscopic Treatments

  • Per-Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM): A newer Minimally invasive procedure involving dissection of LES muscle fibres.

Fluctuant swelling in the hip Cold abscess can develop from Pott’s abscess Pain on the passive extension of the hip joint is seen It develops more commonly through the hematogenous route in immunocompromised patients and elderly.
Which of the following would be the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.explanation:
Meckel's Diverticulum

Clinical features
  • Most common ectopic mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum is Gastric > Pancreatic > Colonic (Option A) (Option B, C ruled out)
  • The most common symptom in children is gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Ulcers are formed in the surrounding area due to acid secreted from the ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum, which causes bleeding.
  • The most common symptom in adults is abdominal pain.
  • Complications: Volvulus, intestinal obstruction, intussusceptions, diverticulitis and perforation.

Investigations
  • 99mTc-pertechnetate scan: Absorbed by the ectopic gastric mucosa, allowing for visualisation.
  • Plain abdominal radiography, CT abdomen, and ultrasonography are seldom useful.
  • Endoscopy: Helpful in false-negative cases, but not the investigation of choice.

Management

  • Healthy base (no induration or ulceration): Diverculectomy (excision of the diverticulum only) + anastomosis.
  • Unhealthy base (ulceration, presence of gastric mucosa): Resection of the small bowel with the diverticulum + anastomosis.
  • Incidentally detected during an elective surgery: Diverculectomy.

questions.text: What is true about gall bladder carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign

options.label: C
options.text: Gallstones and gallbladder cancer are easily distinguished clinically

options.label: D
options.text: Median survival is less than 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. Median survival is less than 6 months
questions.explanation:
Gallbladder Cancer

Etiology

  • Gallstones
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction
  • Cholesterosis of the gallbladder
  • Gallbladder polyps
  • Porcelain gallbladder
  • Infections and inflammatory conditions
    • Chronic typhoid carriers
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections
  • Other factors:
    • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
    • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
    • Nitrosamines
    • Carcinogens

Clinical features

  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases (Option C ruled out)
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage) (Option B ruled out)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage) (Option A ruled out)

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnostic Imaging
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging and Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

Management
  • Early disease:
    • For disease confined to the mucosa, if there is negative cystic duct margin and no recurrence on imaging- No further treatment
  • For transmural disease- Radical en bloc resection of gallbladder fossa, liver wedge, and regional lymph nodes.
  • Advanced Cancer:
    • Non-operative palliative care.
    • Endoscopic/percutaneous methods to relieve obstructive jaundice.
  • Adenocarcinoma:
    • Early-stage limited to mucosa:
  • No additional treatment is required if imaging shows no recurrence.
  • Beyond mucosa:
    • Extensive surgery involving gallbladder fossa, a portion of the liver, and nearby lymph nodes.

questions.explanation:
Duodenal ulcer perforation
  • Common with anterior duodenal ulcers.
  • Presents with an acute abdomen with sudden-onset, severe epigastric pain, rebound tenderness, and air under the diaphragm in the radiograph. (Option B)
  • Management:
    • Non-surgical:
      • Nil per-oral
      • IV antibiotics and PPIs
    • Surgical:
      • Initial empirical antibiotic treatment.
      • The perforation is approached by a small upper midline incision
      • Perforations <1cm are closed primarily and buttressed with a well-vascularized omentum
      • Larger perforations & with fibrotic edges: Modified Graham's Repair or Omental Patch Repair.
      • The vascularized pedicle of the greater omentum is patched over the defect.

Bleeding duodenal ulcer
  • A posterior duodenal ulcer is the one that usually bleeds.
  • It is due to the involvement of the gastroduodenal artery.
  • This leads to hematemesis, melena or both i.e., an upper GI bleed.
  • Bleeding is commonly associated with intake of NSAIDs.
  • Management:
    • Endoscopic: Done to find the bleeding source and manage bleeds endoscopically. Injection, thermal coagulation, plasma argon coagulation, mechanical clips, and fibrin glue are the methods used. (with or without adrenaline injection).
    • Angiographic management: If endoscopic management fails.
    • Surgical management:
      • Exposure to the ulcer and ligation of the duodenum are the principles here.
      • Duodenotomy
      • Ligation of the bleeding vessel with truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty

Gastric Outlet Obstruction (GOO)
  • Acute inflammation of the duodenum or pylorus leads to mechanical obstruction with a functional gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Presents with nausea, early satiety, vomiting, loss of weight, and anorexia.

Hourglass deformity

It is seen in chronic gastric ulcers with scarring and fibrosis.

Pyloric stenosis

It is seen in cases of chronic ulcers, which lead to stricture and constriction of the pylorus.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding gastric carcinoma: It is mostly hereditary E-cadherin adhesion defect is seen in diffuse types of gastric CA. Wnt signaling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric CA. Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis.
questions.explanation:
Category

Risk factors

Diet

High-salt foods (e.g., salted and smoked meats), low intake of fruits and vegetables

N-nitroso compounds are formed from nitrates in high-salt and smoked foods, Similar to tobacco smoke

Lifestyle habits

Smoking, alcohol, poor food preparation (smoked, salted), lack of refrigeration, contaminated drinking water, low socioeconomic status

Infectious Causes

H- pylori infection: M/c infectious cause of gastric cancer.

Mechanism: Chronic inflammation leading to atrophic gastritis, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia, and carcinoma

Polyps
  • Adenomatous polyps (risk of malignancy)
  • In multiple polyps, the largest one is excised, and biopsy from others is taken.

Hereditary factors
  • E-cadherin (CDH1) gene mutation (hereditary diffuse gastric cancer) (Statement B)
  • Hereditary cancer syndromes
  • Li- Fraumeni syndrome

Medications

Proton pump inhibitors (long-term use creates low-acid environment achlorhydria; Risk for H. pylori colonisation)

Other risk factors

Gastric ulcers, pernicious anaemia (achlorhydria), obesity, Epstein-Barr virus, prior abdominal irradiation (for testicular cancer or Hodgkin’s lymphoma), prior gastric surgery, male sex

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has a barium enema as shown in the picture below?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Diverticulosis

Diverticulosis

Definition

Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.

Etiology

Diet: A low-fiber diet increases colon pressure.

Age: More common in those over 60.

Genetics: Family history may increase risk.

Pathophysiology

Increased pressure: High colon pressure causes weak spots to bulge.

Weak colonic wall: Weak areas, especially where blood vessels enter the mucosa, are prone to forming diverticula.

Characteristics

False diverticula: Involve only the mucosa and submucosa.

Multiple and acquired: Typically multiple and not congenital.

Location: Most commonly in the sigmoid colon, along the mesenteric aspect.

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic; may include mild abdominal discomfort, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.

Diagnosis

 

Colonoscopy: Direct visualization.

CT Scan: Detailed images of the colon.

Barium enema: Less common, shows a characteristic sawtooth appearance

Management

Diet: Increase fiber intake.

Hydration: Drink plenty of fluids.

Exercise: Promotes healthy bowel function.

Complications

Lower GI Bleed: Common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with a low-grade fever of 1-week duration associated with loss of appetite and weight loss. Barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Ileocaecal TB

Feature

Details

Definition

A form of abdominal tuberculosis affecting the ileocecal region, the most common site of gastrointestinal TB.

Why the Ileocecal Region?

Rich in lymphoid tissue, slow transit time, and increased uptake of tubercle bacilli.

Common Symptoms

Right lower quadrant (RLQ) pain, weight loss, fever, diarrhoea/constipation, and abdominal mass.

Differential Diagnoses

Crohn’s disease, appendicitis, colorectal cancer, lymphoma.

Physical Examination

RLQ tenderness, palpable mass, signs of obstruction (in severe cases).

Imaging Findings

Ultrasound/CT scan: Bowel wall thickening, lymphadenopathy, ascites, strictures.

Endoscopic Findings

Colonoscopy: Ulcers, nodularity, strictures in the ileocecal region.

Histopathology

Caseating granulomas, acid-fast bacilli (AFB) on Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

Definitive Diagnosis

AFB culture, PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Treatment

Anti-TB Therapy (ATT): Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol (2 months), followed by Rifampicin + Isoniazid (4 months).

Indications for Surgery

Bowel obstruction, perforation, abscess, stricture, and unresponsiveness to ATT.

Surgical Options

Limited resection (if necessary), stricturoplasty (for non-resectable strictures).

questions.text: Which of the following accurately represents Bormann's classification for gastric carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component

questions.correct_answer: A. Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component:

Bormann Type

Macroscopic Appearance

Key Features

Type I (Polypoid type)

Polypoid or fungating mass

Well-defined borders, grow into the lumen, minimal invasion into the gastric wall, mand ay have a small ulcerated component.

Type II (Ulcerated tumor with distinct borders)

Ulcerated lesion with raised margins

Clearly defined infiltrative edges, but not deeply penetrating into surrounding tissues. (Option B ruled out)

Type III (Ulceroinfiltrative type)

(Option C ruled out)

Deep ulceration with infiltrative margins

Irregular and poorly defined borders, penetrate deeper into the gastric wall, more aggressive than Type II.

Type IV (Diffuse/Infiltrative type – Linitis Plastica)

(Option D ruled out)

Diffuse thickening of the stomach wall

Infiltrative growth without a discrete mass, causes "a leather bottle stomach" appearance, commonly associated with signet-ring cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about colon cancer? 1. Right and left colon cancers can behave differently 2. Colon cancers can be hereditary 3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin 4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver
questions.explanation:
Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. Right and left colon cancers can behave differently.

True

Right-sided colon cancer (proximal) is more likely to present with anemia, occult bleeding, and larger polypoid tumors, while left-sided colon cancer (distal) presents with obstruction, hematochezia, and napkin-ring lesions.

2. Colon cancers can be hereditary.

True

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC/Lynch Syndrome) and Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) are genetic syndromes associated with increased colon cancer risk.

3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin.

True

Studies suggest that metformin reduces insulin resistance and suppresses colorectal cancer cell proliferation, lowering the risk, especially in diabetic patients.

4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver.

True

The portal venous system drains the colon to the liver, making it the most common site of metastasis. Other common sites include lungs and peritoneum.

questions.text: Nonclinical question: Match the following: 1. Hirschsprung’s disease A. MRCP 2. Posterior urethral valve B. CT scan 3. Choledochal cyst C. Rectal biopsy 4. Intussusception D. Micturating cystourethrogram
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

Condition

Investigation

Explanation

Hirschsprung’s disease

Rectal biopsy (C)

Gold standard test to confirm absence of ganglion cells in the colonic submucosa, leading to functional obstruction.

Posterior urethral valve

Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) (D)

Identifies posterior urethral obstruction due to congenital valves in male infants, causing urinary retention and hydronephrosis.

Choledochal cyst

MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) (A)

Best non-invasive imaging modality to visualize biliary tree anomalies, including cystic dilatation of the common bile duct.

Intussusception

CT scan (B) (Ultrasound is first-line for children)

CT scan shows the "target sign" in adults, while USG is preferred for children, showing characteristic concentric rings.

questions.text: A patient with rectal prolapse underwent surgery. The postoperative image is given below. Identify the Procedure.
questions.explanation:
Aspect
Abdominal Rectopexy
Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

Partial

Complete
  • Mucosal
  • There is no descent of the muscular layer.
  • It is the most common type of rectal prolapse.
  • History of mass per anum, It is pink in colour and circumferential.

 
  • Complete-full thickness.
  • The descent contains all layers of the rectum (i.e. including the muscular layer).
  • Complete descent of rectum as mass per anum circumferentially, which is red in colour. Mass is usually reducible and painless.
  • It may be associated with uterine prolapse (uterine procidentia) in females.
  • Fecal incontinence (75%) is very common.
  • Bleeding can occur because of the congestion.
  • Sepsis, discharge, fever, and anaemia are other features.

questions.text: A man in his middle age arrives with a gradual onset of challenges while swallowing both solid and liquid substances over the course of 8 months. The results of a barium swallow test conducted are provided below. What additional examinations should be conducted for this individual?
questions.explanation:
Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia such as tumors.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following can be seen in this child? A. Bilious vomiting B. Visible peristalsis from left to right C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia D. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

Definition

It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 - 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age. (Statement A ruled out)
    • Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus.
  • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
    • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
    • Pyloric length > 14 mm
    • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic "string sign" with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

questions.explanation:
Mesenteric cysts

Definition
  • It presents as a painless abdominal swelling in the umbilical region.
  • Commonly seen in the 2nd decade of life.
  • There is a band of resonance in front of the cyst.

Tillaux's triad for mesenteric cysts
  • A soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region. (Option A ruled out)
  • Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery (Tillaux Sign)
  • A zone of resonance all around.

Complications
  • Torsion of cysts can lead to volvulus of the adjacent bowel.
  • Rupture of the cyst.
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst.
  • Infection

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the Chicago classification, which type of achalasia does the patient have?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Type III

Chicago Classification of Esophageal Motility (4.0)

Esophageal Disorder

Description

Values

1. Achalasia

Type I

Minimal contractility (Option B ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis

Type II

Esophageal pan-pressurization (Option A ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis with ≥ 20% pan-esophageal pressurisation

Type III

Spastic contractions (Option D)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, ≥ 20% spastic contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

2. Esophagogastric Junction Outflow Obstruction (EGJOO)

Elevated integrated relaxation pressure (IRP) with preserved peristalsis

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, some preserved peristalsis

3. Distal Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Premature (rapid) contractions with normal IRP

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% premature contractions (DL < 4.5 s)

4. Hypercontractile (Jackhammer) Esophagus

Extremely strong peristaltic contractions

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% hypercontractile contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

5. Ineffective Esophageal Motility (IEM)

Weak or failed peristalsis

Normal IRP, > 50% ineffective swallows (DCI < 450 mmHg·s·cm for weak peristalsis)

6. Absent Contractility

Complete lack of esophageal contractility

Normal IRP, 100% failed peristalsis

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered neuroendocrine tumour in the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Insulinoma

Category

Details

Definition

A rare, typically benign tumour of the pancreatic islet cells that produce excess insulin.

Clinical Features

Whipple's Triad:

  • Documented low blood glucose levels during symptomatic episodes
  • Relief of symptoms upon administration of glucose
  • Symptoms often occur during fasting or after exercise

Symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., sweating, palpitations, confusion, visual disturbances, seizures)

Diagnosis
  • Gold-standard test for diagnosing insulinoma is a 72-hour fast.
  • Combination of plasma glucose < 55 mg/dL + insulin level ≥ 3 microUnits/mL + C peptide level ≥ to 0.6 ng/mL + proinsulin ≥ 5 pmol/L, + negative sulfonylurea level indicates that the hypoglycemia induction is by hyperinsulinemia
  • Insulin/glucose ratio > 0.4 is diagnostic
  • Imaging:
    • CT, MRI, EUS

Management
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.
  • Medical management with diazoxide or octreotide for non-surgical candidates or unresectable tumours.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN Type I)

Cause

  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma

(Most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)
  • All the four glands can be included.
  • Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection

Pancreatic adenoma

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)

questions.text: What does the given barium swallow film show?
questions.explanation:
Zenker's diverticulum

Clinical features:
  • Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • Gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Regurgitation at night from undigested food causes cough and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Halitosis(Chronic bad breathe)
  • Malnourished due to dysphagia.
  • Associated hiatus hernia

Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow provides information regarding the size, location, and character of the mucosal lining.

  • Endoscopy reveals fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum.

Treatment:

 
  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy was done through a cervical approach.
  • Dohlman’s procedure: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope.
  • Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using an endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is a primary motility disorder (Option B ruled out) characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

(Option A & D ruled out)

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

 

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris. It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

questions.text: The likely diagnosis for a newborn infant presenting with signs of intestinal obstruction, as indicated by the x-ray image and CT abdomen showing an annular pancreas, is:
questions.explanation:
Duodenal Atresia

Pathophysiology
  • Failed recanalisation of intestinal lumen during gestation

Associated Conditions
  • Prematurity (50%)
  • Congenital anomalies (heart disease, malrotation, annular pancreas, etc.)
  • Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 21)

Clinical Presentation
  • Bilious vomiting without abdominal distention.
  • Symptoms typically present within the first few days of life.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed by the double bubble sign on the abdominal X-ray and prenatal ultrasonography.

Treatment
  • Initial: Nasogastric decompression and IV fluids
  • Definitive: Surgical repair (Duodenoduodenostomy)
  • Postoperative care: Gastrostomy tube, nutritional support

questions.text: A patient who underwent Nissen’s fundoplication was seen in the ward during evening rounds. He is asymptomatic at present and has stable vitals. What is the next line of management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax

questions.explanation:
Management of GERD

Lifestyle Changes
  • Elevate the head of the bed
  • Avoid lying down after meals
  • Quit smoking

Medical management
  • Antacids: Neutralize stomach acid
  • H2-receptor antagonists: Ranitidine, Famotidine
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): Omeprazole, Esomeprazole

Surgical management

Antireflux operation: 3 components

  • Restoration of the intra-abdominal segment of the esophagus
  • Crural repair
  • Reinforcement of the LES by the upper stomach or prosthesis.

Fundoplication: A surgical procedure to wrap the top of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to strengthen the sphincter.

  • Complete fundoplication (Nissen)
  • Partial fundoplication: Posteriorly (Toupet) or Anteriorly(Dor, Watson) has few short-term side effects but has a higher long-term failure rate.
  • Transoral Incisionless Fundoplication (TIF): An endoscopic procedure performed through the mouth but may be less effective for severe GERD and not suitable for all patients.
  • Magnetic Sphincter Augmentation (LINX Device): Involves implanting a ring of magnetic beads around the lower oesophagal sphincter to enhance its function and prevent reflux.

questions.text: Which of the following do not require instruments to examine?
questions.explanation:
Rectal exam findings on external and internal inspection:

External Inspection

Internal Inspection

  • Pilonidal sinus

  • Rectal prolapse
  • Internal haemorrhoids
  • Rectal carcinoma
  • Rectal polyps
  • Tenderness with prostatitis or acute appendicitis
  • Malignant or inflammatory conditions of the peritoneum with anterior palpation

questions.text: Identify the incision marked as B
questions.explanation:
Types of Incisions used for appendicectomy

Name of the incision

Incision area

Type of incision

McBurney's incision

(A in the image)
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision (Option A ruled out)

Lanz incision

(B in the image)

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision (Option D ruled out) / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision

(C in the image)

(Option C ruled out)

 
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis.
  • Upward & laterally by cutting the conjoint tendon.
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carcinoid tumours in the appendix is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behaviour and metastatic potential

options.label: B
options.text: Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Leiberkuhn

options.label: C
options.text: Most common location is the base of the appendix

options.label: D
options.text: Most common tumor of the appendix

questions.correct_answer: C. Most common location is the base of the appendix
questions.explanation:
Carcinoid tumor of the appendix (aka Argentaffinoma)

Definition

(Options A & D ruled out)
  • They are neuroendocrine tumours that originate from the enterochromaffin cells (also known as Kulchitsky cells) of the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
  • They are considered the most common tumours of the appendix.

MC Location

Tip of the appendix

Clinical Presentation

Mostly discovered incidentally during surgery

Larger tumours may cause abdominal pain, flushing, and diarrhoea due to hormone secretion

Hormone Secretion

Secretes serotonin and other vasoactive substances.

Risk of Metastasis

(Option A ruled out)
  • Low for tumours <2 cm
  • Higher for tumours>2 cm

Diagnosis

Confirmed by histopathological examination

Treatment
  • <2 cm: Appendectomy
  • >2 cm: Right hemicolectomy

questions.text: The most common type of gastric sarcoma:
questions.explanation:
Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)

Mutations
  • Most common- c-KIT/CD117
  • Others:
    • PDGFR- beta
    • Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)- Small baby( Pediatric GIST)

Mechanism

KIT (c-kit) is a proto-oncogene encoding a receptor tyrosine kinase. Mutations result in constant activation of KIT signalling, driving tumour growth and survival.

Common Locations
  • Stomach: 60-70% of cases.
  • Small Intestine: 20-30%.
  • Other Areas: Colon, rectum, and oesophagus (less common).

Treatment
  • Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors - Imatinib
  • Surgical management

questions.text: What structures are contained within the anterior pararenal space? Head, neck, and body of the pancreas Adrenal gland, kidney, ureters Aorta, inferior vena cava Ascending and descending colon
questions.explanation:
Retroperitoneal spaces

Anterior pararenal space

It contains the head, neck, and body of the pancreas (the tail of the pancreas is within the splenorenal ligament), the ascending and descending colon, and the duodenum (except for the proximal first segment).

Perirenal space

This includes the adrenal gland, kidney, ureters, and renal vessels. (Statement 2 ruled out)

Posterior pararenal space

It is surrounded by the posterior leaf of the renal fascia and muscles of the posterior abdominal wall, contains no major organs and is composed primarily of fat, blood vessels, and lymphatics.

There is also a fourth, less well-defined space known as the great vessel space. It lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and psoas muscles and contains the aorta, inferior vena cava, and surrounding fat. (Statement 3 ruled out)

questions.text: What electrolyte imbalance is commonly observed in patients with this postoperative condition, as depicted in the provided x-ray?
questions.explanation:
Paralytic ileus

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g. hypokalemia) (Option B)
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Clinical Features
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Abdominal discomfort.
  • Non-colicky pain.
  • Vomiting.
  • Non-passage of feces and flatus.
  • Absence of bowel sounds.

Investigations

 

IOC: Abdominal X-ray.

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

Management

 

Decompression: Nasogastric aspiration.

 

Diet: Restrict oral intake until bowel sounds return or the patient starts passing faeces and flatus.

 

Treatment of Underlying Cause:

  • Correct dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia).
  • Discontinue medications affecting motility (e.g., opiates).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a past history of peptic ulcer disease. Physical examination reveals rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?

Bochdalek hernia

Aspect

Description

It is due to the failure of the fusion of the pleuroperitoneal canal, which leads to direct communication between the pleura and peritoneum on the left side.

Contents

Colon, occasionally small bowel or stomach

Associated Conditions
  • Hypoplasia (potentially bilateral)
  • Decreased bronchial branch generation
  • Extension of tunica media beyond respiratory bronchioles
  • Decreased total lung mass

Diagnostic Features
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory embarrassment
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Bowel sounds on the left side of the chest
  • Mediastinal shift towards the right side
  • Intestinal obstruction

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a neonate who is brought to the hospital with complaints of forceful vomiting that is not accompanied by bile after feeding? The child appears lethargic and dehydrated, and abdominal examination shows visible movements of the stomach. A barium meal was conducted, and the image provided is shown below.
questions.explanation:
Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

Definition

It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 and 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age.
    • Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus.
  • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
    • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
    • Pyloric length > 14 mm
    • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic ¸ with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 5-year-old child with abdominal swelling, mild discomfort, no pain or vomiting, and a fluctuant soft swelling that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the mesentery attachment, as seen in the outpatient department?

The image below shows an image of the anus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and it occurs when one of your anus glands becomes clogged and infected? Pus and fluid accumulate in the anal gland, resulting in an excruciatingly painful abscess around your anus?

Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old male patient who visited the surgery OPD with a history of occasional discharge of pus with a slight presence of blood from an external opening in the perianal region, despite multiple attempts at drainage? The examination of the perianal region is depicted below.
questions.explanation:
Fistula-in-ano

Causes
  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Parks classification

Type 1 - Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2 - Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3 - Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4 - Extra- sphincteric (1%)

questions.text: An infant of 12 weeks presented with the following defect in the umbilical area. Identify the condition.
A patient, after heavy drinking of alcohol presents with multiple episodes of vomiting and hematemesis. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Mallory-Weiss syndrome

Definition

It is defined as mucosal lacerations in the gastric mucosa at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction that are caused by forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining.

Epidemiology
  • It accounts for 10-15% of acute upper gastrointestinal haemorrhages.
  • The greatest risk for massive haemorrhage is alcoholic patients with preexisting portal hypertension.

Risk Factors
  • Alcoholic patients with intense vomiting after binge drinking.
  • Forceful abdominal contractions against a closed cardia.
  • Any patient with repeated episodes of emesis.
  • Portal hypertension in alcoholic patients.

Diagnosis
  • The patient's history is crucial.
  • It can be confirmed with endoscopy.
  • Retroflexion manoeuvre during endoscopy is used to view the area below the gastroesophageal junction.

Symptoms

Vomiting, hematemesis, upper abdominal pain, hypotension, tachycardia

Complications

Rarely massive bleeding associated with portal hypertension

Treatment

Endoscopic methods (multipolar electrocoagulation, epinephrine injection, band ligation), angiographic transarterial embolisation, rarely surgery

Prognosis

Generally good with appropriate endoscopic treatment

questions.text: What could be the possible cause of sweating and diarrhea occurring within 20 minutes of eating in a patient who has undergone gastrectomy?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Early Dumping

Features

Early Dumping Syndrome

Late Dumping Syndrome

Time of occurrence

Within 30 minutes to 1 hour after a meal

1 to 3 hours after a meal

Pathophysiology

Rapid emptying of stomach contents into the small intestine, leading to a shift of fluid into the gut and rapid absorption of glucose

Reactive hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin release

Symptoms

Sweating, flushing, dizziness, lightheadedness, rapid heartbeat, palpitations, abdominal cramps, bloating, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

Weakness, fatigue, lightheadedness, sweating, palpitations, confusion, hunger

Alvarado Score aka MANTRELS Score

MANTREL

Score

Migratory pain

1

1

1

2

  • Score of 9-10: Diagnosis is certain

  • Score of 7-8: High likely hood of diagnosis

  • Score of 5-6: Equivocal (most dangerous)

  • Score of 1-4: Negative for acute appendicitis

questions.text: ​​​​​​​In the OPD, a 35-year-old male presented with concerns of passing dark-colored stools . Following an endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. Which anatomical structure serves as a distinguishing point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Ligament of Treitz:

References:

  • ↳ The Ligament of Treitz, also known as the suspensory muscle of the duodenum, is a fibrous band located at the junction between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and the jejunum (the second part of the small intestine).
  • ↳ This anatomical landmark serves as a useful reference point for distinguishing between upper and lower GI bleeding.
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Option A - Ampulla of Vater: The Ampulla of Vater is the site where the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct join and enter the duodenum.
  • ↳ Option A - Ampulla of Vater:
  • ↳ Option C - Superior duodenal flexure: The superior duodenal flexure refers to the curved segment of the duodenum, where it transitions from the descending part to the horizontal part.
  • ↳ Option C - Superior duodenal flexure:
  • ↳ Option D - Ileocecal junction: The ileocecal junction is the point where the small intestine (ileum) connects to the large intestine (cecum).
  • ↳ Option D - Ileocecal junction:
    • References:

    • ↳ It is a fibrous band connecting the fourth part of the duodenum to the diaphragm, situated at the level of the duodenojejunal flexure.
    • ↳ Used to differentiate between the upper and lower gastrointestinal tract, marking the transition between the proximal (upper) small intestine (duodenum) and the distal (lower) small intestine (jejunum).
    • ↳ Important in diagnosing and classifying gastrointestinal bleeding. It helps differentiate upper GI bleeding (above the Ligament of Treitz) from lower GI bleeding (below it).
    • ↳ A crucial landmark in various gastrointestinal surgeries, including gastric bypass and small intestine resection. Surgeons use it as a reference point to identify the duodenojejunal junction and plan interventions accordingly.

questions.text: Provide your opinion on the diagnosis based on a radiographic image displayed of a 65-year-old male experiencing acute abdominal pain.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Colocolic intussu

Finding

Description

Associated Pathology

Free air under the diaphragm

Air is visualized under the diaphragm, indicating air escaping into the peritoneal cavity.

Perforation of a viscus (e.g., gastric or duodenal ulcer)

Thumbprinting

Thickened mucosal folds with a "thumbprint" appearance.

Ischemic colitis, colonic inflammation

Corkscrew appearance

Tortuous and dilated appearance of the esophagus.

Diffuse esophageal spasm

Double bubble sign

Two air-filled bubbles are seen in the abdomen, representing dilated stomach and duodenum.

Duodenal atresia or stenosis in infants

Thumb sign

Enlarged epiglottis with a thumb-like appearance.

Epiglottitis
